newsitem.title: UK: Bunkers help Euro fuel oil, low sulph still hesitant.
newsitem.headline: Bunkers help Euro fuel oil, low sulph still hesitant.

text.p: European fuel barges perked up on Thursday with the help of pre-weekend bunker demand while low sulphur markets were still hesitant, traders said.
After a deal at $81 fob a tonne for high sulphur in Rotterdam, barge offers rose to $83 a tonne, $1-$2 higher than yesterday. Bunker demand was reported healthy.
"There is no news affecting it. Its just bumping along the bottom as normal," said a trader.
Low sulphur swaps were fractionally weaker, reflecting the market's rather stilted character, traders said.

A German trader was heard to have bought the British barrels sold to a U.S. refiner by a dealer last Friday. Last week's deal at $95 a tonne fob surprised the market so much no other material has been seen traded since.
The German trader was heard to have paid the average of June quotes plus a small premium and was believed to be taking the material to Puerto Rico.
"This material is just getting passed around and nothing else is really happening," said one dealer.
Russian material was appearing with greater frequency in the north, traders said.
A cracked M-100 was sold into the Spanish bunker market yesterday and the same buyer bought a vessel of M-100 straight-run for refinery use.
